titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller University records, Special Events and Activities, Botany Exhibit
A Guide to the Rockefeller University records, Special Events and Activities, Botany Exhibit FA882

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2016-11-04 08:19:57 -0400.

revisiondesc.item: Paper finding aid converted to EAD/XML by AureXus in 2010. Imported into the Archvistsâ€™ Toolkit by Becky Robbins.

did.unittitle: Rockefeller University records, Special Events and Activities, Botany Exhibit

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: In 1967 McGraw Hill published for the New York Botanical Garden, Harold W. Rickett's WILD FLOWERS OF THE UNITED STATES. Celebrating this publication The Rockefeller University arranged an exhibit entitled "Three Centuries of Botany in North America." The publication of Harold Rickett's volume 1 was made possible by the National Committee for the Wild Flowers of the United States under the leadership of Mrs. David Rockefeller and Mr. Diarmuid C. Russell. The publication was dedicated to David and Peggy Rockefeller.

The Exhibit was open March 22-April 14, 1967 in The Abby Aldrich Building on The Rockefeller University campus. Rare books were loaned by The New York Public Library, The New York Botanical Garden, The American Philosophical Society, The Library Company of Philadelphia, The Royal Botanic Gardens, The William L. Clements Library, The New York Academy of Medicine, The New Church Library, Stechert-Hafner, Inc.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A record of the exhibit was made in black and white photographs. They are for identification only and are not intended to be of reproductive quality (negatives are part of the record). A number of color transparencies of unusual quality were made and prints were used for exhibition purposes. The master transparency is filed with the loose-leaf pages of the exhibit record, but additional copies were made and form part of this collection.
